titleStmt.title: Structure and hemodynamics of vascular networks in the chorioallantoic membrane of the chicken

affiliation.orgName: 3 Institute of Anatomy, University of Bern,
4 Department of Physiology, University of Arizona,

address.addrLine: Tucson, Arizona Charitéplatz 1, D-10117 Berlin, Germany

analytic.title: Structure and hemodynamics of vascular networks in the chorioallantoic membrane of the chicken

biblStruct.note: Submitted 12 October 2015; accepted in final form 4 July 2016

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: The chick chorioallantoic membrane (CAM) is extensively used as an in vivo model.
Here, structure and hemodynamics of CAM vessel trees were analyzed and compared with predictions of Murray's law.
CAM microvascular networks of Hamburger-Hamilton stage 40 chick embryos were scanned by videomicroscopy.
Three networks with ϳ3,800, 580, and 480 segments were digitally reconstructed, neglecting the capillary mesh.
Vessel diameters (D) and segment lengths were measured, and generation numbers and junctional exponents at bifurcations were derived.
In selected vessels, flow velocities (v) and hematocrit were measured.

Hemodynamic simulations, incorporating the branching of capillaries from preterminal vessels, were used to estimate v, volume flow, shear stress (), and pressure for all segments of the largest network.

For individual arteriovenous flow pathways, terminal arterial and venous generation numbers are negatively correlated, leading to low variability of total topological and morphological pathway lengths.
Arteriolar velocity is proportional to diameter (vϰD 1.03 measured, vϰD 0.93 modeling), giving nearly uniform levels (ϰD 0.05 ).
Venular trees exhibit slightly higher exponents (vϰD 1.3 , ϰD 0.38 ).
Junctional exponents at divergent and convergent bifurcations were 2.05 Ϯ 1.13 and 1.97 Ϯ 0.95 (mean Ϯ SD) in contrast to the value 3 predicted by Murray's law.
In accordance with Murray's law, levels are (nearly) maintained in CAM arterial (venular) trees, suggesting vascular adaptation to shear stress.
Arterial and venous trees show an interdigitating arrangement providing homogeneous flow pathway properties and have preterminal capillary branches.
These properties may facilitate efficient oxygen exchange in the CAM during rapid embryonic growth.
chick embryo; cardiovascular modeling; angiogenesis; Murray's law; microcirculation
Extensive in vivo data were used for reconstruction and modeling of hemodynamics of chorioallantoic membrane vascular trees.
The interdigitating network structure provides homogeneous flow pathway properties, facilitating oxygen exchange.
Shear stress levels are nearly uniform in arterioles, suggesting structural adaption of diameters in response to wall shear stress.
THE CHICK CHORIOALLANTOIC membrane (CAM) is an extraembryonic tissue consisting of two fused epidermal layers (chorion ectoderm and allantoic endoderm
dermal double layer in which a dense vascular network is formed.
In its final position the CAM is located directly adjacent to the egg shell (55).

As the avian homolog of the mammalian placenta, the CAM mediates oxygen exchange from about day 4 of embryo development [Hamburger-Hamilton (HH) stage 23; see Ref. 25] until hatching of the chick (35,66).
The CAM is also responsible for calcium mobilization from the egg shell to promote embryonic bone mineralization (17,68).
Blood vessels grow rapidly in the emerging CAM.
Until day 8 of incubation (HH33-HH35), vessels are immature and deprived of a complete basal lamina or a smooth muscle cell layer.
Until day 11 (HH37-HH38), capillaries show a very high proliferation rate with a subsequent decline.
By day 12 to 13, spatial expansion of the CAM is complete, and the capillary plexus reaches its definitive location at the surface of the ectodermal layer beneath the egg shell (5).
The position of the capillaries within the chorionic ectoderm remains unchanged from day 14 until hatching (5).
The CAM network is connected to the embryonic systemic circulation by the allantoic arteries and veins (69).
Because of the easy access to the CAM and high reproducibility, simplicity, and cost effectiveness, the CAM assay has found wide use as an in vivo model (53,64).
The CAM of White Leghorn chicken is by far the most frequently used CAM model (53).
Fewer studies involve the CAM of Japanese quail or reptiles, i.e., turtles.
Whereas all types show similar network architecture, vascular density in the avian CAM is significantly higher than in the reptile CAM (7).

In numerous studies, the CAM has been used to investigate gas exchange (8,34,71), angiogenesis (54,73), anti-angiogenesis (56,70), tumor development (1,9), metastasis (3,59), transplant reactions (33), and drug toxicity (19).
Despite its extensive use, the CAM vasculature itself has not yet been systematically characterized.
Previous studies primarily focused on either morphometric or hemodynamic features of the CAM microcirculation.

Attempts to map CAM vasculature remained incomplete, considering only statistical data for vascular density and vessel length (52) or the first three precapillary and postcapillary vessel orders (10), and most data were obtained analyzing single vessels.
Thus, information about CAM vessel trees and their characteristics is scarce.
The main goal of the current study is to provide a quantitative description of the structure and hemodynamics of the CAM vasculature.

Such a description is needed to understand the functional significance of the structural patterns observed in this vasculature, and can also provide insight into the biological mechanisms that govern vascular growth and remodeling during development.

Theoretical models have been used as a powerful tool for the investigation of such phenomena (38 -40, 50, 60), and the results presented here provide a basis for application of modeling approaches to the investigation of the CAM vasculature.

Vascular network structures have often been analyzed with reference to Murray's law (36), which states that an optimal trade-off between the metabolic costs of blood volume (calling for small vessel diameters) and the costs of pumping blood (calling for large vessel diameters) is achieved if wall shear stress is uniform throughout the vascular network and blood volume flow rate is proportional to vessel diameter cubed.
A further goal of the present study is to compare the flow patterns in arteriolar and venular trees in the CAM with the predictions of Murray's law.
Ex ovo CAM model.

Fertilized eggs of White Leghorn chicken (Gallus gallus; VALO BioMedia, Cuxhaven, Germany) were incubated in horizontal position in a humidified environment at 37.5°C, modified after Auerbach et al. (4).

After 72 h, egg shells were cracked open under aseptic conditions, and the contents, including the embryo, were transferred to cell culture dishes (internal diameter: 87 mm; TPP, Trasadingen, Switzerland) where incubation was continued until chick embryos reached stage HH40 -HH42 (21).
Intravital microscopy.

Cell culture dishes were placed on a custommade stage consisting of a temperature-controlled and humidified microscopic chamber that was mounted on an intravital microscope (Leitz Wetzlar long working distance objective, magnification ϫ4, NA 0.12, parallel trans-and epi-illumination) allowing CAM live observation for up to 24 h.
Microscopic images were recorded by a CCD camera (CX 9000; MBF Bioscience, Magdeburg, Germany) using image analysis software (Neurolucida, version 8; MBF Bioscience).
Blood flow velocity measurement.
The method for measurement of flow velocity using a spatial correlation approach has been described in detail earlier (31,51).

CAM microvessels were scanned by use of an asynchronous double-strobe illumination (11360-1; Chadwick-Helmuth, El Monte, CA) to allow recording of the microvessels at two closely spaced time instances.
Moving blood cells generate light intensity patterns in the microvessels that are shifted in position between two successive recordings.
This shift, indicating the distance traveled by the blood cells, was measured off-line by correlation analysis of the light patterns with a digital image analysis system.
With a minimal time delay of 0.5 ms between two successive recordings and a maximal measurable position shift of 20 m the upper limit of velocity measurement was ϳ40 mm/s (20 m/0.5 ms).
Blood vessel hematocrit and hemoglobin oxygen saturation measurement.
A previously developed multispectral technique was used to determine intravascular hematocrit levels and hemoglobin oxygen saturation (65).
In short, CAM vessels were recorded using monochromatic light with wavelength varied from 500 to 598 nm in steps of 2 nm.
For each wavelength, the optical density of each image pixel was calculated from measured light intensities.

For intravascular pixels, changes of optical density with changing wavelength were then analyzed according to a general model, assuming dependence of the optical density for a given wavelength on the vessel's hemoglobin content, the level of hemoglobin saturation, and the thickness of the vessel in the direction of the optical axis.
Absorption data of preparations with known hemoglobin content served as a reference.
Preparation of vascular casts and electron microscopy was performed according to Djonov et al. (13).
CAM vasculature was perfused with a freshly prepared Mercox solution (Vilene, Tokyo, Japan) containing 0.1 ml of accelerator/5 ml of resin.
After polymerization of resin, CAMs were excised and transferred to 7.5% potassium hydroxide for the dissolution of surrounding unperfused tissue.
After treatment with potassium hydroxide corrosion casts were mounted on aluminum stabs and sputtered with 10 nm gold.
The specimens and their pattern of vasculature and the condition of the endothelial tissue were then studied with a Phillips scanning electron microscope (Philips XL 30) at different magnifications.

In three stage HH40 chick embryos, selected CAM areas, including arteriolar trees (consisting of arteriolar segments connecting divergent branch points) and venular trees (consisting of venular segments connecting convergent branch points), were scanned using intravital microscopy.
A photomontage (Fig. 1A) was used for vessel tree reconstruction (50), providing information about vessel length, diameter, and connection pattern of arteriolar and venular segments.
The capillary mesh was not included in the morphological reconstruction due to the technical difficulty of visualizing such a large number of vessels (Ͼ100,000 segments for a CAM area of Ͻ2 cm 2 ).
In the present analysis, this was addressed in two ways:

For the analysis of individual arteriovenous (A-V) flow pathways, artificial A-V connections were introduced as links between precapillary arterioles and the nearest postcapillary venules (see Pathway length).

For hemodynamic simulations, the preterminal connection of CAM vessels to the mesh was accounted for by a simple parametric model (see Simulation of network flows): as shown in Fig. 1, B-D, CAM arteries and veins supply or drain the capillary mesh not solely by their terminal branches but also via short preterminal side branches arising from proximal vessel segments.
A similar branching pattern has been observed in other respiratory organs.
In the human lung, for example, precapillary side branches and even capillaries arise directly from arteries of diameter up to 100 m or more to feed the capillary meshwork (22).

div.head: Structural Analysis of CAM Vessel Trees

p.s: Vessel segment topology.

The topological position of a vessel segment within the arteriolar or venular vessel tree is described by its generation number, representing the number of branch points between the segment and the main feeding (or draining) vessel of the network.
Generation number 1 is assigned to the feeding arteriole and the draining venule entering or leaving the reconstructed area.
At each branch point, the generation number of a vessel is increased by 1 (43,49).
Pathway length.

An erythrocyte entering the network via the feeding arteriole can traverse the vascular network along many different pathways to the point where it finally leaves the network via the main draining venule.
Arterial (venous) pathways extend from the main feeding arteriole (main draining venule) to the capillary compartment.

Two different parameters to describe the dimension of arteriolar (venular) pathways were used: the topological pathway length, which corresponds to the number of branch points included in this pathway, and is thus equivalent to the generation number of the respective terminal arteriole (venule), and the morphological pathway length, corresponding to the summed vessel length along the arteriolar (venular) pathway.
The total topological (morphological) pathway length was calculated as the sum of topological (morphological) arterial and venous pathway lengths of a selected AV pathway.
The A-V connections mentioned above were not included in the calculation of total morphological or topological pathway lengths.
Two flow pathways and their A-V connections are indicated in Fig. 2D.
Analysis of scaling properties.

An established measure of the scaling properties of a vessel tree is to assess relations between diameters of the vessels joined at a bifurcation estimating the "bifur-cation exponent" or "junctional exponent" x defined for each bifurcation by:

div.formula: D 0 x ϭ D 1 x ϩ D 2 x (1

p.s: where D0 is the diameter of the parent vessel and D1 and D2 are the diameters of the daughter vessels.
According to Murray's law (36), this exponent is expected to equal 3. Here, it was determined iteratively.
For bifurcations with very asymmetric daughter branches, numerical problems can arise.
Thus, only those bifurcations were included in further analysis where the diameters of the daughter vessels were smaller than the diameter of the mother vessel and where 0 Ͻ x Ͻ 10.
In addition, the area ratio ␤ and the symmetry ratio ␥ were calculated according to

div.formula: ␥ ϭ D 2 ⁄ D 1 with D 2 Յ D 1 (3)

div.head: Hemodynamic Analysis of CAM Vessel Trees

p.s: Simulation of network flows.
The mathematical simulation of convective blood transport in microvascular networks used here has been described in detail earlier (41, 44, 49 -51).

Experimental data of network structure, i.e., connection matrix, segment lengths, and diameters of all vessels (excluding capillaries) and boundary conditions (see below), served as input to the model calculations.
An iterative algorithm was used to calculate pressure drop, flow rate, wall shear stress, and hematocrit for all vessel segments of a given vascular network.
In the present analysis, the capillary mesh and the immediate preterminal side branches were not included in the simplified morphological reconstruction as described above.

Blood flow entering or leaving the capillary mesh via these side branches was therefore not explicitly included in the simulation, leading to a potential violation of the mass conservation principle for distal vessels (flow loss or gain).
To avoid this error and to allow estimation of correct flow values for distal vessels, a simplified parametric representation of this effect was used.

In a first step, flow loss and gain were neglected, so that all flow passed through the terminal A-V connections, and conductance C, volume flow Q, and pressure drop P for each vessel segment were calculated.
For arterioles, an exponential flow decay due to flow loss, analogous to electric signal attenuation along a cable, was then assumed, and the updated flow Q= in each segment was determined as

div.formula: Q Ј ϭ Q in ϫ e Ϫ L Lc (4)

p.s: where Qin is vessel inflow and L is vessel length.
Lc is a length constant introduced to adjust the extent of arteriolar flow loss (or venular flow gain) along the vessel.
Pressure drops in each segment are correspondingly reduced.

Because the initially simulated flow velocities without flow loss or gain were significantly higher than experimentally measured values for a diameter range of 10 m Ͻ D Ͻ 70 m, the correction was applied in this diameter range.
The length constants were adjusted to fit simulated velocities for a given vessel diameter (Fig. 3) to those obtained by direct measurements (Fig. 4).
An analogous procedure was used for venules, to relate flows in distal (upstream) segments to those in proximal (downstream) segments.

The length constants (Lc) were assumed to vary linearly with vessel diameter (D) considering two separate diameter ranges ( where the constants a and b for arterioles and venules were determined separately by a fit to the experimental data.
Statistical analysis was performed using SigmaPlot (version 11; Systat Software, San Jose, CA).
Statistical significance was assumed for P Ͻ 0.01.
Wall shear stress levels and segment lengths were compared with a Mann-Whitney U-test.
In double logarithmic plots,
Three networks with 3,860 (reference network), 488 (network II), and 586 (network III) vessel segments were digi-tally reconstructed and analyzed.
Here, data for the reference network are given.

Despite the fact that morphological and topological parameters are influenced by the size and selection of the respective reconstruction area, egg-toegg variability of structural and topological parameters is low.
Hemodynamic simulations were restricted to the refer-
ence network due to its size relative to the two minor networks.
For the structural and hemodynamic analyses of the networks, only blood vessels that were supplied by the biggest arteriole and drained by the main venule were considered.
These "main path"-vessel trees provide most consistent topological and hemodynamic conditions least influenced by additional boundary vessels.

For this reason (and because arterioarterial shunt segments occurring in CAM vasculature were excluded from the final analysis) the arteriolar and venular vessel numbers (n) considered in the analyses do not add up to the total vessel count given above.
In the reference network, a CAM area of ϳ1.7 cm 2 containing two major arterial and one major venous vessel tree was reconstructed (Figs. 1, 2A, and 2B).
The reconstructed vessel trees down to the precapillary level consisted of 1,128 (1,208) arteriolar (venular) main path segments, respectively.
Diameters (flow rates) of the two main feeding arterioles and the major draining venule were 261 m (38.1 l/min), 172 m (10.7 l/min), and 390 m (403.8 l/min).
Smaller secondary boundary vessels entered (n ϭ 31) or left (n ϭ 14) the observed region.
Structure and topology.
Structural analysis of the CAM vessel trees showed nearly equal distributions of vessel diameters and individual segment lengths for arterial and venous vessels (Fig. 6, A and B).
Mean diameter was 46.3 m for arteries and 49.1 m for veins.
There was no statistically significant difference between segment lengths for arterioles and venules of the same diameter range.

Segment lengths were Distribution of topological (generation number) and morphological pathway lengths for arteries and veins is given in Fig. 6, C and D. AV pathways consist of an arterial section extending from the main arteriole down to the capillary compartment and a venous section extending from the latter up to the main venule.
In the CAM, arterial and venous vessel trees are arranged in an interdigitating pattern.
Consequently, long arterial pathways are connected (via the capillary mesh) to short venous pathways, and vice versa (Fig. 2, C and D).
Thus, for individual AV pathways, generation numbers and morphological pathway lengths of the respective precapillary arterioles and postcapillary venules are inversely correlated (Figs.
2D, 6E, and 6F).
This corresponds to a relatively homogeneous distribution of total topological and morphological pathway lengths (CV 0.14 and 0.11, respectively).
Total AV pathways in average consisted of 50.7 vessel segments (49.7 branch points) and had a length of 14.5 mm (SUM, Fig. 6, C and D).
The differences in mean morphological and topological pathway length between arterial and venous trees mainly reflect the differences in tree sizes in the reconstructed area.
In vivo hematocrit, blood flow velocity, and hemoglobin oxygen saturation.
Hematocrit was measured in arterioles (n ϭ 152 in N ϭ 3 embryos, diameter 15-147 m) and venules (n ϭ 153, N ϭ 3, diameter 15-147 m).
Mean hematocrit was 0.17 Ϯ 0.03 for arteries and 0.15 Ϯ 0.03 for veins.

Experimental measurements of blood flow velocity for arterial (n ϭ 124, N ϭ 7, diameter 7-193 m) and venous vessels (n ϭ 123, N ϭ 7, diameter 7-192 m) are shown in Fig. 4 with a indicating the slope of linear regressions.
Whereas arterial blood flow velocity (a ϭ 1.03) grows nearly proportionally to vessel diameter, venous vessels (a ϭ 1.51) exhibit a stronger increase.
Figure 7 shows a 2D measurement of oxygen saturation of hemoglobin for a section of the CAM obtained by multispectral imaging.
The capillary mesh is not shown.
According to the respiratory function of the CAM, arterial vessels carry deoxygenated blood to the capillary mesh in which oxygen uptake takes place.
Oxygenated blood is collected by venous vessels and transported back to the chick embryo.
Hemodynamic analysis.

Results from the computer simulation of hemodynamics for the reconstructed network are shown in Figs. 3 and 8. Calculated pressure values ranged from 9.3 mmHg (main arteries) to 4.0 mmHg (major vein).

These values are in good agreement with previously published in vivo data for day 14 (day 15) White Leghorn chick embryos where mean arterial pressures of 7.9 mmHg (8.6 mmHg) have been reported (2,18).
Pressure drops along the arterial and venous tree are fairly similar (2.4 vs. 2.9 mmHg), reflecting the structural and topological symmetry of these two vessel tree types in the CAM.

The fact that the pressure drop is slightly lower on the arterial side might be due to the selection of the reconstructed area with a somewhat larger venous tree and longer venous pathways (8.8 vs. 5.7 mm; Fig. 6, C and D).
Wall shear stress was [mean Ϯ SD (median)] 4.47 Ϯ 2.70 dyn/cm 2 (3.97 dyn/cm 2 ) in arterioles and 4.65 Ϯ 3.37 dyn/cm 2 (3.68 dyn/cm 2 ) in venules.
Differences in shear stress levels were not significant between the two vessel types.
In arterioles, shear stress levels remained largely unchanged throughout the vascular tree (a ϭ 0.05; Figs.
3A and 8B).
Venules showed a slight significant decrease of wall shear stress levels with decreasing vessel diameter (a ϭ 0.38; Figs.
3B and 8B).
Especially in small vessels (diameter Ͻ20 m), wall shear stress distribution was strongly heterogeneous (CV 0.77 for arterioles; 1.04 for venules).
In vessels with a diameter above 100 m, variation was smaller (0.28 and 0.42; see also Fig. 9).
Arterial blood flow velocity increased almost proportionally to vessel diameter (a ϭ 0.93; Fig. 3C) in concordance with the in vivo data (a ϭ 1.03).
Compared with arteries, venous vessels showed stronger increase of flow velocity with vessel diameter (a ϭ 1.30 and 1.51, respectively; Fig. 3D).
For arterial trees, volume flow increased closely by the third power of vessel diameter (a ϭ 2.93) while in venous trees the value (a ϭ 3.31) is somewhat higher (Fig. 3, E and F).

In arteries, none of the respective a values for wall shear stress, flow velocity, and volume flow (0.05, 0.93, and 2.93) were significantly different from Murray's predictions of 0, 1, and 3, respectively.
In contrast, a values for veins (0.38, 1.30, and 3.30) were significantly higher, indicating a systematic deviation from Murray's law.
The range of calculated viscosity values was 1.0 -1.6 cP for arteries and 1.0 -1.5 cP for veins.
Bifurcation parameters.
Table 1 gives an overview of the analyzed bifurcation parameters.
Junctional exponent x, area ratio ␤, and symmetry ratio ␥ are each given for different classes with respect to the diameter D 0 of the parent vessel of
a bifurcation.
A junctional exponent x of 0 Ͻ x Ͻ 10 was observed in 70% (72%) of the arterial (venous) bifurcations analyzed.

For these bifurcations, the mean junctional exponent was 2.05 Ϯ 1.13 (CV 0.55) for arteries and 1.97 Ϯ 0.95 (CV 0.48) for veins, i.e., substantially below the value of 3 predicted by Murray for optimized vessel trees.
Mean area ratio and mean symmetry ratio were fairly similar in arteries (␤ ϭ 0.94 Ϯ 0.25; ␥ ϭ 0.53 Ϯ 0.24) and veins (␤ ϭ 0.92 Ϯ 0.24; ␥ ϭ 0.56 Ϯ 0.24).
Both x and ␤ increase slightly with increasing parent vessel size (except for large arteries between 60 and 100 m) while symmetry ratio simultaneously declines.
In this study, we performed an integrated analysis of CAM vascular trees in stage HH40 (day 14) chick embryos, combining intravital microscopy with mathematical model simulations.

The aim was to analyze structural and topological parameters with respect to their suitability for performing the two main tasks of CAM microvasculature: convective blood transport through the network and large scale substance (especially gas) exchange with the surroundings, and to test the hypothesis that embryonic CAM vessel tree morphology follows Murray's principle of optimization for minimal cost.

We found that arterial (and somewhat less venous) CAM vessel trees are in line with a Murray-type optimization of hemodynamic parameters that predicts constant wall shear stress levels and proportionality of blood flow velocity (volume flow) to vessel diameter (vessel diameter cubed), thus minimizing the summed cost for blood convective transport and vessel maintenance.
Intriguingly, this cannot be derived from the mean junctional exponent, which should equal x ϭ 3 according to Murray's law.
On the other hand, substrate exchange in CAM vasculature may be facilitated by homogenized AV pathway lengths re-sulting from the interdigitating design of cocurrent arterioles and venules.

In addition, there is a dense capillary mesh that is fed and drained not only at the very terminal vessel ends of arteriolar and venular trees but also via numerous small segments arising directly from the sides of bigger conduit arteries and veins, a pattern that may increase effectiveness of capillary mesh perfusion and thus of substrate exchange.
Network architecture.
In the mature systemic circulation, a parallel arrangement of paired arterioles and countercurrent venules is frequently observed.
By contrast, the CAM vascular system at this stage consists of interdigitating arterioles and venules, with long arterial pathways connected to short venous pathways and vice versa (Fig. 2).

This design allows relative homogeneity of both morphological and topological AV pathway lengths with CV values of 0.11 and 0.14, respectively (Fig. 6), which are less than one-half of corresponding values found in, e.g., the rat mesentery (CV 0.35 and 0.32), used as an example for mature systemic vasculature (49).

For the mesentery, complete data sets on morphological and topological properties are available, and it may be particularly suitable for comparison with the CAM since it is also almost two-dimensional and does not exhibit a relevant level of vascular tone [resting tone in CAM microvessels (Ͻ10%); unpublished data and Ref . 50].
Vessel number and morphology.
In self-contained dichotomous networks fed and drained by one single artery and vein, respectively, the number of arteries and veins would be equal (30).

For the reconstructed networks here, this does not strictly apply for two reasons: first, small arterioarterial shunts can be observed in the CAM vasculature, causing an imbalance between arterial and venular segments, and, second, the reconstructed networks are not fully self-contained with their boundaries arbitrarily chosen.
To reduce the impact of the arbitrary network borders only vessels that were supplied by the biggest arteriole and drained by the main venule were included in the network analysis as described above.
AV asymmetry of diameters, with veins exceeding arteries, is a common feature in the systemic circulation.
Arterial vessels are adapted to high transmural pressure, resulting in increased wall thickness and reduced vessel diameter (47,63).
In the pulmonary circulation, however, diameter, length, and branching ratios of the two vessel types are fairly similar, reflecting lower pressure differences (67).
This is also seen in the CAM, where only low pressure differences occur (Fig. 8A) and AV asymmetry of diameters is small (Fig. 6A).
Bifurcation morphology.
Structural bifurcation parameters such as the junctional exponent x, area ratio ␤, and symmetry ratio ␥ have been widely used as criteria to describe optimality properties of vascular beds (57).

Following Murray's suggestion that minimization of energy consumption of a given network corresponds to uniform shear stress levels and proportionality of blood flow velocity (volume flow) to vessel diameter (vessel diameter cubed) (36), as well as x ϭ 3 and ␤ Ͼ 1, alternative optimization principles have been proposed.
Kurz and Sandau postulated x ϭ 2.7 and ␤ Ͼ 1, corresponding to constant wall tension and minimal use of wall material (29,72).

West et al., analyzing optimal transport conditions from an allometric viewpoint, proposed x ϭ 2 and ␤ ϭ 1 for transport vessels and x ϭ 3 and ␤ Ͼ 1 for smaller exchange vessels, reflecting an area-preserving and blood flow velocity-preserving design of arterial bifurcations (29,72).
A large variation of x as found in the present study (CV ϳ0.5) has also been reported for other tissues, i.e., human coronary arteries (x ranging from 1.5 to 14.2 with a CV of 0.5) (24).
Murray's law has been described to hold well in vascular beds of several species and tissues (24,74,75).

However, some studies provided evidence that it is less accurate in the largest vessels (pulmonary artery and aorta) and smallest vessels (capillaries) and that x ϭ 3 is not exactly met in reality (25,61).
Also, a systematic deviation from Murray's law has been shown for the AV passage in microvascular networks (47).
Analysis of wall shear stress.

For the CAM arteriolar trees analyzed here, mean wall shear stress levels are constant, irrespective of vessel diameter, and blood flow velocity and volume flow increase proportionally to vessel diameter and the third power of vessel diameter, respectively.
Thus, none of the respective slope values of linear regressions in double logarithmic plots (a ϭ 0.05, 0.93, and 2.93) were significantly different from Murray's predictions (0, 1, and 3).

From these results, integrating morphological properties over entire vascular trees, it can be concluded that CAM arterial trees are in line with a Murray-type optimization of hemodynamic and metabolic cost, in spite of the results described above for individual bifurcation morphology.

For the venular tree studied, mean wall shear stress increased significantly with vessel diameter (a ϭ 0.38), and augmentation of blood flow velocity and volume flow with vessel diameter (a ϭ 1.30 and 3.30) was stronger than expected from Murray's law.
In other words, large venules exhibited lower than expected diameter for a given volume flow, leading to higher than expected shear stress.

Thus, the hemodynamic network analysis proves close adherence to a shear stress control according to Murray's law in contrast to an analysis strictly based on individual bifurcation diameters, which rather suggests that CAM microvascular networks are not tightly optimized according to Murray's postulate.
Several effects contribute to the deficiency of the bifurcation-based analysis.
In the derivation of the respective a values it is assumed that the flow resistance in the respective branches is strictly proportional to the fourth power of diameters measured at the bifurcation.
For realistic networks this is not the case, since the downstream vessel trees differ substantially in topology and morphology.
These differences are reflected in a hemodynamic analysis but not in the determina-tion of bifurcation parameters.

Also, flow resistance and thus flow distribution is very sensitive to vessel diameter due to the fourth power relation, and experimental measurement errors will have a strong and nonlinear effect on the derived bifurcation parameters.

Consequently, morphological bifurcation data and bifurcation parameters aimed at testing hemodynamic properties and adaptation characteristics of vascular trees have to be interpreted with significant caution.
Compared with the data reported for other tissues, absolute shear stress values in CAM vessels are low.
In the cat mesentery, Lipowsky et
to 40 dyn/cm 2 (55 m) in veins, respectively.
Highest variability of wall shear stress was found in small arterioles (32).

In the cat sartorius, wall shear stress ranges were 60 dyn/cm 2 (60 m) to 140 dyn/cm 2 (15 m) in arteries and 3 dyn/cm 2 (18 m) to 10 dyn/cm 2 in veins (72 m) as demonstrated by House and Johnson (23) and Popel and Johnson (40).
Later, it has been shown that wall shear stress strongly correlates with intravascular pressure and decreases gradually from the arterial to the venous ends of vascular networks (47).
Our data confirm the finding of Lipowsky and Zweifach of a high variability of wall shear stress in smaller vessels (32).
With regard to the pressure-shear hypothesis (47) the low shear stress values observed in the CAM may be explained by the low pressure values found in this vasculature.

The observed relationship between hemodynamic parameters (shear stress, volume flow) and morphological parameters (vessel diameter) results from structural vascular adaptation and suggests that responses to wall shear stress play an important role in vascular adaptation.
Vascular systems grow and remodel in response to hemodynamic stimuli as to maintain wall shear stress at a certain set point, i.e., to reach steady-state conditions (47).

Koller et al. showed in extensive studies that changes in wall shear stress evoke vessel diameter changes, providing a negative-feedback control for the maintenance of constant wall shear stress levels (27,28).
Residual deviations from this set point trigger further network adaptation.

In this context, it has to be considered that vascular adaptation to hemodynamic parameters (shear stress, pressure) alone is unstable and leads to the collapse of parallel flow pathways to a single AV connection (20,48).

To generate stable vascular networks, vascular responses to hemodynamic signals have to be balanced by local and propagated vascular responses to metabolic conditions of the tissue, evoking vessel diameter changes (45).

The observation of constant shear stress in arteriolar trees suggests that the strength of local and propagated metabolic signals and of pressure-induced signals does not exhibit a systematic dependence on diameter in arterioles.

Correspondingly, the slight increase of wall shear stress with vessel diameter in CAM venules reflects a changed balance in which higher hemodynamic signals evoking diameter increase are compensated by a decreased strength of local and/or propagated metabolic signals.

The lower level of metabolic signals in CAM venules may relate to the fact that oxygen saturation and partial pressure in these vessels is high (Fig. 7), since CAM vasculature is responsible for oxygen uptake (42,48).

While mean values of shear stress in arterial trees follow predictions of a hemodynamic adaptation, the observed variability of wall shear stress in individual vessel segments is consistent with a significant role for metabolic signals in the adaptation of both arterial and venous vascular trees.
For both types of trees, wall shear stress variability increases with decreasing vessel diameter (Fig. 9).

Wall shear stress values in vessels below 20 m in diameter show a more than twofold variability (CV 0.77, 1.04 for arteries and veins, respectively) compared with vessels bigger than 100 m (CV 0.28, 0.42).
With decreasing vessel diameter there is an increasing heterogeneity of vessel topological and morphological conditions (26), even in the relatively regular vascular array of the CAM.

From two small arterioles (of the same diameter, blood flow, and metabolic demand of the supplied tissue region), for example, the arteriole branching from a large conduit vessel will usually experience higher substrate supply by the flowing blood than the arteriole located at the distal end of an extended arterial tree.
Resulting metabolic stimuli for diameter increase reflecting the local demand-to-supply ratio may thus also differ.
Vessels with high shear stress are likely to exhibit low metabolic and/or propagated stimuli and vice versa.
Even in small CAM vessels the variation of wall shear stress is lower than observed in other tissues.
In the rat mesentery, for example, CV values for shear rate ranging from 0.92 in arterioles to 1.62 in capillaries have been reported.
Several studies have been carried out to investigate CAM development under altered metabolic conditions, i.e., hypoxia.

Exposure to low oxygen levels during development leads to an increase of vascular density of arterioles and veins (14 -16) due to an increase of vessels below 10 m in diameter, favoring the precapillary side.
Network topology, vessel diameters, and vessel lengths of individual vessels are not significantly altered under hypoxia (16).
However, incubation under hypoxia represents a gross interference with the normal development of the CAM and affects both arteries and veins simultaneously.
Further studies are thus needed to dissect the role of metabolic signals and oxygen levels and underlying molecular mechanisms for adaptation of arteriolar and venular vessels in the CAM.
Angiogenesis and structural adaptation in the CAM.

The distinctive structural and hemodynamic characteristics of the CAM demonstrated in this study reflect the processes of vascular growth and remodeling occurring during the development of this tissue (11,12,55).
By embryonic day 8, a dense capillary plexus forms in the CAM.

Within this mesh, a subset of the vessels becomes enlarged and displaced laterally, forming arteriolar and venular trees (a process that may be called "emergent angiogenesis") lying adjacent to the capillary plexus (Fig. 1B).

A notable feature of this structure is the presence of connections between these trees and the underlying plexus along the length of proximal vessel tree segments, and not only at their termini (Fig. 1, C and D).

Values are presented as means Ϯ SD; n, no. of included parent vessels or bifurcations, respectively, that met the criterion of 0 Ͻ x Ͻ10, which was true for 70% *(72% **) of the arterial (venous) bifurcations analyzed.
Junctional exponent x, area ratio ß, and symmetry ratio ␥ for arteries (ART) and veins (VEN) are given for different diameter classes, D0, of the parent vessel of each bifurcation.
Parent vessels were classified as small (Ͻ45 m of diameter), intermediate (45-60 m), and large (60-100 m) according to Djonov et al. (13).
Both junctional exponent (except for large arterial vessels) and area ratio increase with increasing vessel diameter, whereas the symmetry ratio declines.
This mechanism of vascular network formation differs substantially from the process of sprouting angiogenesis that has been observed in mature systemic vascular beds, including muscle and mesentery.

The formation of a functional network structure by sprouting angiogenesis involves a highly stochastic process requiring an overabundant growth of sprouts combined with structural adaptation and pruning to ensure an adequate flow distribution (46).
In contrast, the process occurring in the CAM provides a very rapid and efficient mechanism to generate a dense vascular mesh to meet the oxygen needs of the growing embryo within a few days (37).

This process is aided by the interdigitating arrangement of arterioles and venules, which leads to relatively homogeneous path lengths and is therefore capable of producing relatively uniform perfusion without extensive structural remodeling to compensate for variable flow pathway lengths (42).
Thus, from major vessels down to the capillary level, CAM vasculature is characterized by a remarkable degree of homogeneity.
Additionally, resting tone of both CAM arteries and veins is low (Ͻ10%, unpublished data), since the CAM is responsible for the continuous delivery of oxygen to a continuously growing embryo.
Physiological states of rest and work that are typical for other organs, e.g., the skeletal muscle, do not exist in the CAM.

The above-mentioned features are the major reasons as to why the CAM model offers stable and consistent conditions for any experimental alteration providing high intraindividual and interindividual reliability and reproducibility.
The conditions that promote this homogeneity of path lengths remain largely unknown.
However, it is noteworthy that the left and right allantoic arteries and the allantoic vein remain widely separated during the rapid growth of the CAM (21a).
This wide separation of major vessels permits the growth of interdigitating arteriolar and venular trees with relatively few vessel crossings.
Such a pattern is less likely to occur when the main feeding and draining vessels are closely paired, as is the case in many tissues, including skeletal muscle and mesentery.
In summary, the CAM of the chick is widely used as an experimental system for studying angiogenesis and vascular responses.
The CAM vasculature provides a model for vascular beds whose primary function is gas exchange, such as the fetoplacental circulation in mammals and the pulmonary circulation.
The present studies provide quantitative information on the hemodynamic properties of the CAM vasculature.
In arteriolar trees, diameters decline according to the predictions of Murray's law, so that shear stress is approximately constant.
However, the shear stress declines somewhat with decreasing diameter in the venules, showing a slight deviation from Murray's law.
Relationships between vessel diameters at bifurcations do not allow to judge vascular adaptation characteristics and (dis)agreement with Murray's law properly.
The lengths of AV flow pathways are substantially more homogeneous than seen in mature systemic vascular beds such as mesentery and skeletal muscle.

This difference may result from the mechanisms of angiogenesis occurring in the CAM, where the arteriolar and venular networks emerge from a preexisting capillary plexus, and are not formed by sprouting angiogenesis.
10 m Ͻ D Ͻ 25 m and 25 m Յ D Ͻ 70 m).
The length constants for diameters of 10, 25, and 70 m were 15, 150, and 10,000 m for arterioles and 40, 200, and 5,000 m for venules.
The amount of arteriolar flow loss is visualized in Fig. 5. From 70 m down to 15 m of diameter, arterioles lose ϳ90% of volume flow to the capillary mesh via preterminal side branches, and
Fig. 1.
Chorioallantoic membrane (CAM) vascular network.

A: an assembly of 15 single photographic frames was used for vessel tree reconstruction (selected region color highlighted), providing information about vessel length, diameter, and location of Ͼ3,800 vessel segments.
Flow direction is indicated for major arterial (filled arrows) and venous (open arrows) vessels.
B-D: scanning electron microscope recordings show the extensive capillary mesh (*) fed by the vessel trees.
C and D: evidence of preterminal branching: before dividing in its terminal segments, an arteriole feeds the capillary mesh via short preterminal vessel branches (arrowheads).
These branches and the capillary mesh were not included in vessel tree reconstruction but numerically accounted for in the model simulation (see MATERIALS AND METHODS).
Fig. 2. Distribution of topological pathway lengths in the reconstructed vascular trees.
A and B: arteries (A) and veins (B) color coded for generation number.
The network is supplied by two major arterial vessels (filled arrows) and drained by one major vein (open arrow).
C: Close-up view of an arterial tree section (filled arrows) and its draining vein (open arrow).

The interdigitating structure of the arterial and venous trees leads to connections between arterioles close to the inflow (low generation, blue) and venous vessels remote from the outflow (high generation, red), and vice versa.
D: 2 different arteriovenous (A-V) pathways are highlighted.
In the "High GenA-path" (solid lines) a long arterial pathway (red) is connected to a short venous pathway (blue).
Accordingly, the generation number of its precapillary arteriole (postcapillary venule) is high (low).
For the "Low GenA-path" (broken lines), these relations are reversed.
For individual flow pathways, the respective generation numbers (pathway lengths) of (to) the precapillary and postcapillary segments have been plotted in Fig.3E(3F).
A-V connections defining the AV pathways are shown in gray.

mean Ϯ SD (median)]: D Ͻ 45 m: 121 Ϯ 66 m (110 m) for arterioles and 130 Ϯ 78 m (114 m) for venules; 45 Յ D Ͻ 60 m: 169 Ϯ 88 m (157 m) for arterioles and 170 Ϯ 100 m (152 m) for venules; 60 Յ D Ͻ 100 m: 207 Ϯ 169 m (166 m) for arterioles and 209 Ϯ 127 m (193 m) for venules; and 100 Յ D Ͻ 250 m: 225 Ϯ 152 m (196 m) for arterioles and 265 Ϯ 223 m (213 m) for venules.
Fig. 5. Arteriolar "flow loss."

A: data for arteriolar volume flow resulting from model simulations neglecting (gray circles, sliding averages in dark gray) and assuming flow loss (black circles, sliding averages in white) are provided showing individual data and sliding averages.
B: the remaining flow in arterioles is given as the quotient of simulated volume flow with flow loss and without flow loss.
From 70 m down to 15 m of diameter, arterioles lose ϳ90% of volume flow to the capillary mesh via preterminal side branches.
Fig. 7. Hemoglobin oxygen saturation in CAM vessels.
Vessel color indicates level of oxygenation (color bar on the right, saturation in %).
Because the CAM serves as a respiratory organ, arterioles (filled arrow) transport deoxygenated blood to the capillary mesh (*, not visible), in which oxygen uptake takes place.
Venous vessels (open arrow) carry oxygenated blood back to the chick embryo.
Fig. 8. Distribution of hemodynamic parameters in the reconstructed vessel trees resulting from mathematical modeling.

Colorcoded representation of intravascular pressure (A), wall shear stress (B), blood flow velocity (C), and volume flow (D) for all vessels supplied by the biggest artery and drained by the main vein (generation number 1 each).
Note the logarithmic color bar scaling in B, C, and D.
Fig.9.
Modified version of Fig.3.
In A-F sliding averages (black) are given showing that the dependence of shear stress (velocity, flow) to vessel diameter is nearly linear.
For calculation of sliding averages, data subsets of n ϭ 500 were used.
At the upper border of the dataset (e.g., only 499 shear stress values remaining) subset size for sliding averages was reduced correspondingly (e.g., n ϭ 499 and so on).
In G and H, heterogeneity of wall shear stress is shown.
It is given as the sliding SDs of shear stress residuals.
It becomes obvious that, for both arteries and veins, heterogeneity is particularly distinctive in small vessels of Ͻ20 m.
